I througth you have read the reply of patch set 6:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/776568/6/neutron/tests/fullstack/test_ovs_dhcp_extension.py

VM needs to receive the RA notification from radvd which is handled by router and L3 agent.

I'm not sure if You need all of that in that test. IMO You could only:

1. Spawn VM plugged to the private network,
2. Check if IP address(es) are configured properly inside the vm's namespace

Such test would be much faster and less resource heavy. Please remember that in the fullstack tests You have access to the "fake VM" so You can check everything there.

The router's "radvd" is used for notifying DHCPv6 client the RA flags of "Autonomous flag", "Managed flag" and  "Other flag". Otherwise, the DHCPv6 request will no work in right settings. Actually, we have no test coverage for router "radvd" before, we did not verify if it really works for Neutron. If one day, radvd is going to upgrade with something bad to Neutron, we have no way to know that until the users meet it in production deployment. So, here can be a win-win case, we test DHCP extension with radvd's real functionalities.
I still think that we should make this test as "light" as possible, so L3 agent isn't necessary.

All these resources is not real VM, it is just namespace. I don't think it is heavy. The test case is ping from VM1 to VM2, and ping from VM2 to VM1. Ping inside the namespace where the device is resident looks a bit insufficient. And we already have similar cases here:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/fullstack/test_logging.py
Namespace isn't heave but You need to spawn L3 agent, create router, etc. And all of that uses resources. So IMO if we can do it in the lighter way, we should do that.

neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py.message: What if the agent has been down a while and the lease file is stale?  If there is a bug in the logic below let's fix it but I don't think this is foolproof otherwise.

I don't think this is a concern. The static IP assignment is still in the `host` file. If a client does send a broadcast the lease has already expired. DHCP RENEW requests are sent by unicast to the the server that originally offered the lease. So any other instances will not see them anyway. There will be no NAKs due to missing entries in a lease file as a response to a DHCP DISCOVER request. The lease file is only relevant if a client want's to extend it's lease lifetime before it expires.
The only reason I'm aware of why Neutron cares about this file at all is for the case where a DHCP agent is migrated to a different host. Then this ensures that at least for IPv4 the agent knows about potential leases which are still active because the migrated dnsmasq instance lost it's state (ie. the lease file).
The reason why this needs fixing is not to optimize the code but to avoid hiccups in the IPv6 network connectivity when the client has to go through a full renewal because the lease state on the dnsmasq side got discarded. This is especially relevant as systemd-networkd had a bug which resulted in long time without IPv6 address: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/12623 While this is clearly a (now fixed) bug in systemd-networkd it can be worked around by not discarding the lease state.

I don't think this is a problem as the lease file contains a timestamp when the lease will expire. So the stale leases will just be disregarded and pruned by dnsmasq. And as the clients which received these leases also know that they have expired, they either already received a new lease form another agent or should not expect to be able to renew the lease without going through a full DHCPDISCOVER/DHCPREQUEST cycle.

I guess we would have to check that when a failover occurs when one agent has been offline, i.e. the other dhcp-agent is stopped and a second started, that a client asking this dnsmasq instance (i think broadcast in that case), doesn't get a NAK since it's lease won't be here.  That's what we're trying to avoid.

Does the file write save us a lot of time?

This could work for non HA environments where the dnsmasq process is restarted and the "leases" file preserves all ipv4/6 addresses.

But in case of failover, the now active dnsmasq host won't have any information about any lease. That will not only provoke a hiccup for the IPv6 but also for the IPv4 addresses.

In order to correctly populate the leases file to prevent this issue should be to capture the IAID and the DUID (but this last parameter could be "*"). The client IAID could be read only from the leases file, when dnsmasq populates the value and then store it in the DB, associated to the port (maybe to the IPAllocation child register).

I have an alternate proposal: Instead of just skipping the lease file generation to read the existing lease file and to copy all IPv6 leases and the DUID to the generated lease file. This would solve the common case where the DHCP agent is just restarted (regardless of HA configuration). What do you think?

lib/puppet/functions/qdr_ssl_certificate.message: This is going to have file permission/selinux issues. We should not use puppet functions in this way.

Two questions:

1) Have you looked at whether we can use the certmonger infrastructure to somehow accomplish this securely? Putting private key content into an THT environment file is far from ideal.

2) Assuming it has to be like this, is it possible to use keys like "caCertFileContent", "certFileContent", and "privateKeyFileContent" on the input side so that it's less confusing? It's not good that sometimes "certFile" is meant to hold a filename, and sometimes actual content.

Certmonger serves for certificate/key generation, correct? BUt we need to distribute certs/key generated on STF server side. I'm not sure how would I be able to achieve that with certmonger.

Technically I could use the .*FileContent variables instead, but what would be the point? The .*File variables would be useless anyway, because there are no certificates in containers currently out of the box. Hmm, one use case where wi could use .*FileContent variables would be when user built images for metrics_qdr containers would be used, which contains certificates already. Question is if this is something what operators would want to do. There can be environment files used during deployment with just sslProfiles parameter and deleted after deployment. Seems much user friendlier than the need for container image modification.

1) We talked about this offline and I believe that only "caCertFile" is necessary to solve the problem at hand. Making it easy to import a private key is just making it easy to do an insecure thing, and I fear that users might do this thinking it's the right thing to do.

2) "the point" is just that it's less confusing if the content of a variable has only one set of semantics. If "caCertFile" means content on one line, but means a file path on another line, it can lead to confusion and is harder for others to follow.

glance/quota/keystone.py.message:
what will happen if use_keystone_limits is True but this `quota_name` is not registered yet?

This is why I want to verify whether it is possible to register these limits from glance on startup itself.

> what will happen if use_keystone_limits is True but this `quota_name` is not registered yet?

oslo_limit will consider the limit to be defaulted to zero (i.e. no quota). If you have turned this on, but not configured keystone, I think it's better to allow nothing to be created (no quota) than go unrestricted (unlimited quota), especially since enabling the option says "I _want_ to make sure users don't go over the quota I set."

> This is why I want to verify whether it is possible to register these limits from glance on startup itself.

Yes, you can register a limit in keystone for whatever you want whenever you want (after service registration). Changes in keystone take effect in glance immediately without restarting either service.

You might want to look at my devstack patch which shows when I'm doing this limit registration:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/788056/4/lib/glance

As well as the tempest tests, which show me manipulating the limit for a tenant in realtime and testing that the effects are immediate:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/788346/8/tempest/api/image/v2/test_images.py

Sorry, I missed this:

> This is why I want to verify whether it is possible to register these limits from glance on startup itself.

This would be problematic in two ways:

First, the glance service user would (and should) not have system admin privileges to register new limits.

Second, we would not know what the default value for each limit should be, which is attached to the registered limit.

These are keystone admin-level things that you do at deployment (or upgrade) time, similar to registering the service itself, creating service accounts, roles, etc. As in the devstack patch above, you see we do those things while deploying the system.

@Thomas, can you please help me understand if these two API endpoints you're expecting from Magnum side?

And it would be nice if you can help me understand the response body format and the node object.

TBH, a single /<Cluster>/nodes/<ServerID> is a bit weird for me without the support /<Cluster>/nodes. Personally, I'd like to have /<Cluster>/nodes instead of /<Cluster>/nodegroups/<NodeGroup>/nodes. To get node list of a particular NG, user should use /<Cluster>/nodes?nodegroup=<NodeGroup>, which makes more sense for me.

How do you think? @Spyros

When listing nodes in a node group, the autoscaler's cloud provider code should return a list of the type "Instance" [1], the important fields are:

* ProviderID (openstack:///<server-id>)
* State (Creating, Running, Deleting)
* Error class (Out of quota or Other)
* Error message

So what you have in Node.convert ("uuid", "name", "node_group", "status") has everything except a status reason for the error message.

To get the state in the autoscaler, the first thing I check is the statuses in the kube minions resource list (e.g openstack stack resource list kube-w5axvlfrz5lr-kube_minions-vv7bsojktpi7). But this does not exactly map to the three states expected by the autoscaler. Since all minion stacks go to UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS when resizing a node group, that state could be a creating node or a running node.

To figure out which state an UPDATE_IN_PROGRESS node is, I have to then check the stack resources of the minion itself, like [2], and check if "kube-minion" and "node_config_deployment" are complete. This makes checking this one status quite a long case [3], and I don't know how it would work with this API we're proposing. Maybe listing nodes could return the stack_status but also a node_state that is one of the three expected by the autoscaler?

---

Regarding cluster/nodes or cluster/nodegroup/nodes, I think the first is fine as long as the ?nodegroup=xyz path works essentially like the second option. It shouldn't list everything and then filter the list, it should only query the requested node group.

I'm not sure how useful having /cluster/nodes/<server-id> would be, at least right now. With what you have written so far, the only fields not being returned in the converted nodes list are the cluster ID and project ID, which are both already known. It would have to search through multiple node groups to find the requested node anyway, so at least for the autoscaler it would be more efficient to just list all the nodes and cache the node group IDs of all nodes, instead of making multiple calls to this API with a single node each time.

---

[1] https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/f11443819f46e934eebc7c87916aa8559acba083/cluster-autoscaler/cloudprovider/cloud_provider.go#L175-L222

magnum/api/controllers/v1/cluster_action.message:
How about just use "list" or "nodes"?
And are you guys happy to put the nodes listing as an action of a cluster?

It's better to rely on information from the Magnum API rather than kubernetes node labels (which can be modified).

For reference, by default (1) is called for every node group every 2 minutes, and every 10 seconds for any node groups that are scaling up.

(2) only needs to be called once per scale up ideally, or in the worst case once for each new node node per scale up (if there is a delay between each node being created). The result can then be cached forever.

That's why I suggest to prioritise querying a single node group.

@Spyros, I actually have already got a following patchset locally. But I'm thinking the samething. We may won't create a new object dedicated for "node". In other words, we may need to build the nodes list in memory. Are you guys happy with this?

There are two requirements for the autoscaler.

(1) List all the nodes for a given node group.
(2) Find the node group for a given node (by server ID).

For (1) it must be called often to check the current state, but the result of (2) can be cached so it only needs to be called when there is a new node added.

Given these requirements and considering the complexity/performance, it would be better to restrict the query to a single node group.

Point (2) would require looping over all node groups, but it can be done intelligently (check largest node groups first, cache as much as possible on each call) to minimise the number of calls.
Team, please see my comments in PS3.

FYI, the Nodes() method in the autoscaler is part of nodegroup. https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/master/cluster-autoscaler/cloudprovider/cloud_provider.go#L105

I think we primarily need it to list nodes of nodegroup.


list_nodes is fine

I think the functinality for the autoscaler is more important than the name at this point.

This is an API call the user shouln't need to do. If this is adverised to users more features will be requested. Imagine when you sell this API to the users and they request magnum's API to support PATCH.

For point (2) could we "ask" the kubernetes API about it? The kubernetes API knows the serverID and we can label each node with the nodegroup. It is not there yet, but it can be easily added. I think it makes sense since the server UUID is discovered from the node.


(2) NodeGroupForNode(*apiv1.Node) (NodeGroup, error) https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/73a5cdf928d3b04ac5cbc456a60d5eb084f9cbc1/cluster-autoscaler/cloudprovider/cloud_provider.go#L60

> FYI, the Nodes() method in the autoscaler is part of nodegroup.
 > https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/master/cluster-autoscaler/cloudprovider/cloud_provider.go#L105
 > 
 > I think we primarily need it to list nodes of nodegroup.
 > 
 > 
 > list_nodes is fine

Additionally, since we have different stacks for different NGs, getting the nodes for all NGs will require multiple calls to heat and a transient state being build in memory.


Any feedback based in my comment and not one names? (We can do nodes and stop discussing it.)

So I ask again, why diverge from the direction given by the autoscaler API and do a more error prone implementation?

A client can do:
a.
get all nodes for a given call

b.
iterate over ngs and get all cluster nodes
eg. the autoscaler can do:
NodeGroups() []NodeGroup https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/master/cluster-autoscaler/cloudprovider/cloud_provider.go#L55

and then

Nodes() ([]Instance, error) https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/master/cluster-autoscaler/cloudprovider/cloud_provider.go#L145

armada/handlers/k8s.py.message:
in the commit message you mentioned the watch timeout not reliable, which i assume is why we are adding this `while` loop, did you mean the below `for` loop:
1) times out early
  - probably not, since that would mean a false error would be triggered 
2) never times out
  - in this case what triggers the timeout today?
3) something else?
The watch stream appears to be stopping/exiting early. I've shared some logs with you offline where this behavior was seen and captured.

wouldn't this need to reference the original `timeout` instead of the one which gets updated on each loop this this line? instead of setting `timeout` here, could we instead just use something like `while (time.time() - start) < timeout` on L173?
You're right, good catch. Will fix.

I handled it like this as I'm now enforcing the timeout myself, rather than relying on the timeout sent to the Watcher's watch/stream, because of the odd behavior encountered. If it bails early, we'll get the time it spent waiting and subtract it from the original timeout, then loop and stream events again with the updated value.

That makes sense. I still think we need different variables for the original timeout and updated timeout. For example, if timeout=600s, and 300s elapses on the first iteration of this loop, then the new timeout will equal 300s, then if only 1s elapses on the next iteration, then (time.time() - start) will equal 301s, and so that will get subtracted, and so timeout will equal -1s, which will cause a timeout even though only 301s have elapsed.
Not new with this patchset, but based on the code I think this should read `Saw no events ...` rather than `Saw no delete events ...`

releasenotes/notes/change-the-way-how-ap.message: @Brian, do you mind, as a native English speaker, to check this reno?

I made this re-write, you will have to check it for technical correctness.

    The way the ML2 plugin filters out API extensions which are not supported
    by loaded mechanism drivers has changed.
    Before, the API extension was on the list if at least one of the mechanism drivers
    supported it, but now the extension needs to be supported by all the mechanism
    drivers. If at least one of them filters it out, it will be removed from
    the final list of enabled API extensions.
    Currently, only the OVN mechanism driver is filtering out some of the ML2
    API extensions, thus if that mechanism driver is loaded in Neutron with any other
    mechanism driver, the list of the enabled API extensions may be smaller than it
    was before.

Sure thing. Actually, I'm quite convinced we should move setup_rados() and setup_json_command() to do_setup() as well.

The share manager uses import_object from the oslo import utils when discovering the configured backend, therefore getting the class and creating an instance of it. That happens here https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/share/manager.py#L266-L269.

And the actual driver initialization happens when we select the correct driver (CephFS Native or CephFS NFS), and that happens when we execute do_setup. That happens here  https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/manila/share/manager.py#L343.

__init__ doesn't provide a way to surface errors, so we should limit its usage to loading modules, we shouldn't be establishing connections to the backend or reading any stats.

And I believe that when this class constructor is called, very early on the execution, there are missing attributes that leads us to a failed state which we cannot properly debug.

Hope this clarifies a bit, let me know your thoughts.

Yes, passing --to ip= makes no sense because there's no way to look up the mac of an IP in a system that can have overlapping IPs. You would use --ip-dst for that and then have to specify --eth-dst.

I feel this section could be restructured. Currently it is alternating between a part of the problem and a part of the solution. It might be better to first describe the proper problem statement and then how the agent addresses each of the cases described in the problem statement.
Eg: (I'm not referring to the format, just problems should be described first and later how the proposed solution tackles it)
Problems:
1) when we have client replicated volumes, the replicated volume isn't visible to openstack hence noone to manage it
2) on the target storage side, it is not possible to monitor the state of replicated volumes
Solutions:
1) agent can monitor NVMeoF connections and report changes to storage provisioner, also check for expected and actual state of replicas incase a replacement is needed
2) agent will run on the initiator side
3) additional benefit like not using faulty replicas incase of a re-attachment scenario.

This is just my opinion of making it more clear, others might have different opinions.
Good point, thank you! I did some simple re-ordering of the paragraphs here. Hopefully its better organized and readable now.
what happens if the attached volume (instead of the replica) goes faulty?
Ack

If you are refering to the attached volume being the entire mdraid array, then it is not in the scope of the agent to verify data integrity of the entire raid array (since it cannot make any assumptions as to the actual data).

The faultiness that it detects can only come from the nvme stack (connection problems to individual nvme device), or from the mdraid stack (out of sync aka faulty replica).

Currently, if the entire raid array goes out of sync (ie. there are bits that are out of sync on every one of the replicas) there is nothing as far as I know that the agent can do about it. 

(however there may be some things that can be done to recover from this as part of the entire storage solution, which will involve some orchestration decisions from the storage provisioner, but I don't believe this is currently part of the scope of the agent, but it is a great discussion and I will ask the storage folks designing the entire KumoScale system about what are their takes on this).

we currently don't have os-brick directory and I'm not sure about creating one for a single conf file. (maybe create a different directory since this agent is not specific to os-brick and is not required with other connectors)
We currently store nfs shares file in /etc/cinder but this might be a totally different case.

Great point! I was also really not sure about this, I am currently leaning towards using `/etc/nvme-agent/` for this - will update this in the spec now, and if anyone has more input on this would love to hear it!
does the agent only monitor replicas? if the volume in use goes faulty, what will happen?

Same as my response to your comment on line 59

In short, the only way for the entire (replicated raid1 array) volume to be faulty is if there are bits that are marked as out of sync on every one of its replicas. In this case, at least on the surface, there is no way of knowing what the correct bits are, so this is at least currently out of scope of this agent.

This is a great corner case to be aware of, but even with it it is still more resilient to use raid1 replicated volumes.

ironic/drivers/modules/ipmitool.py.message:
This may not be as big of an issue now, but doing this change will short circuit retries of re-triable errors which were implemented when BMCs returned "Too busy, try again" messages were received, which were mapped into ipmitool immediately exiting with an error code. :\ (Which is how we got the first retriable error for the retry logic, where HP Moonshot BMC IPMI pass-through was returning errors.) Without the retry loop the single error would torpedo a deploy operation completely.

I feel like if we change the conditional below to apply a little bit of sanity to if (num_tries = 0 and ipmitool_retry_logic_present and not err_list) might work?

FWIW, the logic in ipmtiool might have changed since ?1.5.18? days where retry support was present, but it was not retrying in many cases.

My current change aims at keeping ipmitool runtime limited by the configuration option no matter what. Before my patch, ipmitool could take as long as -R squared worth of retries on soft errors (including the timeout failure, what could reflect on the overall run time, ironic task utilization etc).

It now seems to me that the best option would be to leave the current logic around ipmitool as-is, but enforce overall ipmitool runtime via [1]. What do you think?

1. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610007/

sushy/auth.py.message: Seems to make sense, but probably with conditions...
Why set it to False by default (or even provide this parameter) if in the only place you use it you set it to True? I'd just do it by default.
Mm, not much, sorry. What is the use case of connector still linking to an authenticator that is no longer linked to (this) connector?

IIRC Auth obj is supposed to be just a wrapper of BMC credentials (and/or session token, id). In order to cache the session token (until it gets expired) for a particular BMC we can take the approach of maintaining the cache with key as ``node-id+redfish_address`` (or some sort of combination of that sort to uniquely identify the node's BMC) and value as Auth objects. As from the ironic code base [1] what I can notice is we are always creating a new auth object (of type SessionOrBasicAuth) everytime we create the Sushy object. Instead we can use the ``auth`` parameter of Sushy c'tor [2] and can keep passing the cache auth object everytime. And whenever that auth object expires we put in place a mechanism to recreate a new session token pertaining to the node key (of cache) and that gets stored under the same auth object.

    {
      "node-id1+redfish_address1": auth_obj1,  # gets a new session token when the existing one expires,
                                               # but 'auth_obj1' is still the same.
      "node-id2+redfish_address2": auth_obj2,
      ...
    }

So, inherently we keep creating new Sushy objects and new Connection objects (even though internally urllib will take care of using the same session connection from its connection pool for as long as it can), but we keep reusing the same Auth object (session token) for multiple calls to the same BMC (until that expires) and only attempts to recreate a new session token when the existing one expires (again this recreation can be handled by the auth object as it contains the BMC credentials and hence already has the ability to do so).

And for every new Sushy object creation the auth object is set the context of its connection and Redfish root object here [3]. So, I think we can gladly keep creating Sushy and Connection objects.

Do let me know what you think about this approach.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/ironic/blob/master/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/utils.py#L173-L175
[2] https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/master/sushy/main.py#L97
[3] https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/master/sushy/main.py#L114

The idea is to have this method playing on the safe side whenever invoked by the user. With default set to `True`, calling this method would cause the side-effect of  modifying the underlying connection...

Does it make sense?

The use-case is ironic reusing redfish sessions...

We cache authenticator objects in ironic while connections being pooled by urilib under the hood. We want connections to use authenticators for as long as the connection is alive (which is controlled solely by urlib) therefore we might want to call `unset_context(untie_connection=False)`.

But if the connection ceases to exist (by abrupt urllib's decision), we do not want to reference the dead connection from the authenticator object to let the connection be GC'ed. That's why we want to call `unset_context` right after we used the connection.

This gets quite messy indeed. :-(

I think I'm starting to see the problem. We assume one to one relationship between Sushy <-> Connector <-> Authenticator. If we start caching only authenticators, we essentially break this. It may happen that two different Sushy objects will call set_context on the same authenticator in parallel with potentially unpredictable results.

TL;DR we need to either cache the whole Sushy objects or only the session token only :(

It looks like some filters are missed, but I also don't want these duplicated in the two files. Does anyone have suggestions on how we could avoid this duplication? I was hoping we could find an unused local facility but it appears they are all in use.

Looks like local1 is fm-manager
local2 is a bunch of things
local3 is sm
local5 is fm manager events
local6 is sysinv
local7 is horizon

I do not see anything related to local4 so I suspect we could assign all the DC services to local4

I talked to Don and Al and we'd really like to keep the DC syslog configuration in its own file. We think this can be done with the following approach:
1. Remove all local4 configuration from this file.
2. Update the openldap-config package to add a new /etc/syslog-ng/conf.d/openldap.conf file that will filter the slapd logs from local4 and redirect them to /var/log/daemon.log.
3. Update the dc syslog config to move the dc processes to local4. This will be done in the puppet-manifests package.
There is a local4.log file full of slapd logs. That could probably be fixed though by moving the slapd logs to daemon.log, which would allow us to use local4 for the DC services.
Please leave this one here. The filter isn't used currently, but should include all the local facilities.
